questions.question: What is Sales Cloud in Salesforce?

options.A: A CRM solution to manage leads, opportunities, accounts, contacts, forecasting, and sales processes.
options.B: A marketing automation only product for email campaigns.
options.C: A data warehousing offering for analytics outside CRM.
options.D: A serverless compute platform inside Salesforce.

questions.explanation: Sales Cloud is Salesforce's core CRM offering focused on lead-to-cash processes, pipeline management, forecasting, and sales productivity.

questions.question: What are the key objects in Sales Cloud?

options.A: Case, Solution, Asset, Knowledge.
options.B: Lead, Account, Contact, Opportunity, Campaign, Quote, Forecast.
options.C: User, Group, PermissionSet only.
options.D: Report, Dashboard, Dataset only.

questions.explanation: Sales Cloud centers around Lead → Account/Contact → Opportunity and supporting objects like Campaigns, Quotes, and Forecasts.

questions.question: What is a Lead in Sales Cloud?

options.A: A closed deal that has been invoiced.
options.B: A contact linked to an opportunity.
options.C: A support ticket submitted by a customer.
options.D: A prospect who has shown interest but is not yet qualified.

questions.explanation: Leads represent unqualified prospects — people or companies that may become accounts/contacts/opportunities after qualification.

questions.question: What is Lead Conversion?

options.A: Deleting a lead permanently from the system.
options.B: Assigning a lead to a queue only.
options.C: The process of converting a lead into Account, Contact, and optionally Opportunity.
options.D: Exporting leads to a CSV file.

questions.explanation: Lead conversion creates an Account and Contact from the Lead and optionally creates an Opportunity to track potential revenue.

questions.question: Can a lead be converted without creating an Opportunity?

options.A: Yes, Salesforce provides the option to skip creating an Opportunity during conversion.
options.B: No, an Opportunity is always mandatory on conversion.
options.C: Only in Professional Edition.
options.D: Only if a custom trigger blocks Opportunity creation.

questions.explanation: During conversion users can choose not to create an Opportunity, useful when the lead is qualified but not sales-ready.

questions.question: What is an Opportunity?

options.A: A marketing campaign record.
options.B: A potential revenue-generating deal linked to an Account and Contact.
options.C: A support case escalation.
options.D: A read-only snapshot for reporting.

questions.explanation: Opportunities represent potential sales revenue and are tied to accounts/contacts with stages, amounts, and close dates.

questions.question: What are Opportunity Stages?

options.A: Different products in the price book.
options.B: User permission levels for sales reps.
options.C: Different phases of the sales cycle (e.g., Prospecting, Negotiation, Closed Won, Closed Lost).
options.D: API endpoints for opportunity integrations.

questions.explanation: Opportunity stages track progress through the sales lifecycle and usually map to probability percentages.

questions.question: What is Opportunity Probability?

options.A: A system flag for deleted records.
options.B: A currency conversion rate applied to amounts.
options.C: A stage-dependent discount applied to quotes.
options.D: A percentage value that reflects the likelihood of closing a deal, linked to the Opportunity Stage.

questions.explanation: Probability indicates the estimated chance of winning and is often derived from the Opportunity Stage to support forecasting.

questions.question: What is Forecasting in Sales Cloud?

options.A: A tool to schedule data backups.
options.B: An object type for storing leads.
options.C: A visual editor for page layouts.
options.D: A tool to predict future revenue based on Opportunities in the pipeline.

questions.explanation: Forecasting aggregates pipeline values to estimate future revenue — used by reps and managers for targets and planning.

questions.question: What is Collaborative Forecasting?

options.A: A deprecated reporting feature.
options.B: A forecasting tool that allows managers and reps to adjust and share forecasts in real time.
options.C: An automated lead scoring algorithm.
options.D: A template system for quotes.

questions.explanation: Collaborative Forecasting enables users to make manual adjustments, share insights, and collaborate on expected sales figures.

questions.question: Difference between Campaign and Opportunity?

options.A: Campaign → Sales deal; Opportunity → Marketing campaign.
options.B: They are identical objects used interchangeably.
options.C: Campaign → Marketing initiative to generate leads; Opportunity → Sales deal that generates revenue.
options.D: Campaigns are only available in Service Cloud.

questions.explanation: Campaigns track marketing efforts that generate leads; Opportunities track deals and revenue associated with accounts/contacts.

questions.question: How are Campaigns linked to Opportunities?

options.A: They cannot be linked directly.
options.B: Campaign membership automatically creates opportunities.
options.C: Via the Price Book object only.
options.D: Through Campaign Influence, which tracks the impact of campaigns on Opportunities.

questions.explanation: Campaign Influence models attribute which campaigns contributed to an opportunity, helping measure marketing ROI.

questions.question: What are Quotes in Sales Cloud?

options.A: Draft invoices stored outside opportunities.
options.B: System audit logs for price changes.
options.C: A special report type for forecasting.
options.D: Price proposals for Opportunities, containing product, pricing, and discount details.

questions.explanation: Quotes capture pricing details to present to customers and can be synced to opportunities as the primary quote.

questions.question: Can multiple Quotes be linked to one Opportunity?

options.A: No, only a single Quote may exist per Opportunity.
options.B: Yes, but only one Quote can be marked as the primary quote.
options.C: Only if the Opportunity is closed.
options.D: Only for custom objects, not standard Opportunity.

questions.explanation: Salesforce allows multiple quotes per opportunity to compare proposals; one quote can be selected as primary to sync totals.

questions.question: What is Price Book in Sales Cloud?

options.A: A set of users allowed to sell a product.
options.B: A discount schedule engine only for communities.
options.C: A collection of products and their prices that can be linked to Opportunities or Quotes.
options.D: A report template for revenue.

questions.explanation: Price Books define the catalog of products with associated prices; opportunities reference price books to select product prices.

questions.question: What is a Product in Sales Cloud?

options.A: A lead status value.
options.B: A permission set license.
options.C: A workflow rule type.
options.D: A catalog item or service that can be sold through Opportunities and Quotes.

questions.explanation: Products represent goods or services in the catalog and are added to Opportunity Line Items and Quotes for pricing.

questions.question: What is an Order in Sales Cloud?

options.A: A contract to provide products or services, typically created after a Quote is accepted.
options.B: A forecasting bucket.
options.C: A lead assignment rule.
options.D: An Apex job scheduling object.

questions.explanation: Orders formalize the commitment to deliver products/services and are often created from accepted quotes.

questions.question: What is Territory Management?

options.A: A feature that automatically creates opportunities.
options.B: A feature to assign accounts and opportunities to sales reps based on geographic or business rules.
options.C: A case escalation mechanism.
options.D: A UI theme manager for sales pages.

questions.explanation: Territory Management provides rules-based assignment of accounts and opportunities to sales teams or territories for coverage planning.

questions.question: What is Contact Role on Opportunity?

options.A: A permission that controls who can view an opportunity.
options.B: A price book entry for contacts.
options.C: Identifies the role of a Contact (e.g., Decision Maker, Influencer) in an Opportunity.
options.D: A special type of campaign member.

questions.explanation: Contact Roles specify how contacts are involved in a deal (decision maker, approver, influencer), important for sales engagement context.

questions.question: What is a Path in Sales Cloud?

options.A: A way to encrypt opportunity data.
options.B: A report grouping feature only for campaigns.
options.C: A background job runner.
options.D: A guided process UI that helps users progress through Opportunity or Lead stages.

questions.explanation: Path provides a visual, configurable guide (with guidance and key fields) to help reps move records through stages consistently.

questions.question: How do you automate Lead Assignment?

options.A: Using Lead Assignment Rules based on criteria like region, product, or source.
options.B: Only via manual reassignment by users.
options.C: By converting leads automatically without rules.
options.D: Lead assignment cannot be automated in Salesforce.

questions.explanation: Lead Assignment Rules evaluate incoming leads and route them to queues or users based on configured criteria.

questions.question: What is a Lead Queue?

options.A: A holding area where unassigned leads are stored until a rep claims them.
options.B: A scheduled list of leads to be deleted.
options.C: A type of opportunity stage.
options.D: A system batch job name.

questions.explanation: Lead Queues allow teams to share responsibility for new leads; reps can claim leads from the queue for follow-up. (Correct description is A.)

questions.question: What is a Big Deal Alert?

options.A: A naming convention for large accounts only.
options.B: An automatic discount applied to big deals.
options.C: A notification system that alerts sales teams about large Opportunities.
options.D: A report type used only by finance teams.

questions.explanation: Big Deal Alerts notify relevant stakeholders when an opportunity exceeds a threshold so leadership can engage appropriately.

questions.question: What is Einstein Opportunity Scoring?

options.A: A manual scoring field filled by reps.
options.B: An integration with external BI only.
options.C: An automated pipeline generation tool.
options.D: An AI feature that predicts the likelihood of closing an Opportunity based on historical data.

questions.explanation: Einstein Opportunity Scoring uses machine learning to rank opportunities by win probability, helping reps prioritize efforts.

questions.question: Best practices for customizing Sales Cloud?

options.A: Hardcode business rules in triggers only; avoid declarative tooling.
options.B: Add as many fields as possible to every object for future use.
options.C: Use Visualforce for all UI changes regardless of Lightning availability.
options.D: Automate lead routing & follow-ups; use validation rules to ensure data quality; implement Path and Guidance for Success; use Forecasting for pipeline visibility.

questions.explanation: Good practices include automating routine tasks, enforcing data quality, providing guided sales processes, and leveraging forecasting for visibility.
